1. **HOUSEHOLD HISTORY**

   - What year did you start homesteading in Eastern Canada? 1923 Brandon, Man.
   - Where did you set up homesteading? Homestead at Selma, 1917.
   - Where had you been living before that? Brandon, Man.
   - How many people did you prepare meals? Your family consisting of two children.
   - How far was it to your nearest store? 30 miles Brandon.
   - How often could a visit be made to the store? Every two weeks.

   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Bread, flour, sugar, coffee, tea, and other supplies which were usually purchased from stores.

2. **FLOUR AND GRAIN GRINDING**

   - What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Local mill.
   - In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lb.
   - What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? Our own mill.
   - How much did you use Graham flour? 50 lb.
   - Whole wheat flour? Some.
   - Was flour milled locally? Yes. How far away? 30 miles. That year? 1909.
   - What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 6¢.
   - What other grain products did you use? Flax seed for porridge.
   - Cornmeal? Purchased. Whole wheat? Ground. Farina? None.
   - Other?

   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Sometimes.
   - How did you grind it? Hand grinder.
1. First question: Questioning

   What year did you start working? In October 1943, I started working there.

   What was your job? I worked in the bookkeeping department.

   How long have you been there? I've been there since then.

   Have you had any promotions? No, I haven't had any promotions.

   How many people did you supervise? I supervised about 5-6 people.

   How far do you live from work? I live about 2 miles away.

   How often could you visit your parents? I visited them every other week.

   What responsibilities did you usually have in those positions? I was responsible for managing the bookkeeping department.

   Any other interesting experiences or memories? Yes, I remember working during World War II.

2. Next question: Food prices

   What kind of food did you buy at the store? I bought bread, milk, eggs, and vegetables.

   How much did you pay per pound? I paid $0.10 per pound.

   What was the price for a twenty-pound bag of flour? I paid $2.00 for a twenty-pound bag of flour.

   What other goods did you buy? I bought meat, cheese, and canned goods.

   Any other interesting experiences or memories? Yes, I remember buying goods during the rationing period.

   How did you feel about the rationing? I felt frustrated but necessary.

What was your meat supply in the early years? Wild game.

How did you preserve meat? Canning and brine curing mostly also cured bacon from University recipe good too.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so what year was it organized? Think between 20-25.

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Quails.

For how long? Until the present time.

What part did fish play in the family diet? They were only a treat once in a while.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? All three.

Kinds? White, Herring, Salmon.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) well dug by slough in the very early years.

How far was this water from your home? 40 yards.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) see above.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Water was hard to get unless drilled 50-600 ft then it is salty but there are dugouts now and they get good water by digging a well beside them and putting a filter by sand & gravel, clear as crystal.
12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, stream, dugout). If so, how was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank).

Water has been used for cooking, washing, and drinking.

It is only necessary to keep them clean and well stored.

Water should be kept cool and free from impurities.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Yes.

If you made your own, did you use lye? No.

But kinds of laundry soap did the recorer handle? Bar soap.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood, buffalo chips, coal, wood.

Where did you get your fuel? From fields and along roads.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

There are many changes in fuels since the early days when we were lucky if we had coal or wood, when now we have oil for cook stoves as well as heaters and furnaces also propane gas and electricity.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No, although we were 30 miles from town, Dundurn or Stanley, we were fortunate in getting a supply boat.
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the war and list the number of the family members living at that time.

18. How did you earn your first Christmas dinner in January 1910?

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation levels living on only locally purchased foods? Give details. No, although we were 30 miles from town, sometimes Stanley me was fortunate in getting a paycheck.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

In the early days the first thought was there own milk, eggs and butter, also a good garden of vegetables (potatoes and corn) we wouldn't starve on this and wild fruits, strawberries, Saskatoons and pin cherries for jelly and wasn't good?

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

The first year 1907 had to get purchased food but by 1908 we started in to get a good garden and home grown vegetables, pick wild fruit and have our own jam, jellies, pickles and preserved fruit done in an open field. We could learn the art of canning and do now canning of apples, pints pickles to corn pudding which was indefinitely.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

I do not know if there is much information in this or not but I will send it along anyway. I am not as young as I used to be being in my 73rd year, but I hope there is just a little to it. Sincerely,

Mrs. T. C. Johns

Zelma Homemakers Club

Zelma

Sask.
In the early days of the year I thought we'd start our own seeds, tomatoes, also a good garden. Potatoes, peppers, onions, and beans in the garden. We've had a wonderful spring, strawberries, blueberries, and raspberries.

When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and fresh prepared foods?

In the first year 1907 we got started growing and home grown vegetables, pickled meat, and canned vegetables. We've had a wonderful spring, strawberries, blueberries, and raspberries.

I do not know if there is much information on this or not, but I will send it along any way. Jane and I are very glad to have you in our family. In my third year, I hope this is going little by little. Sincerely,

Zelma Johns

Zelma Johnson Club
